I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  discussions  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  in  2012  on  its 
reengagement in Myanmar, the Government of Myanmar requested ADB assistance to improve 
its statistical capacity. ADB joined a multipartner mission to Myanmar 3–5 July 2012 to identify 
and prioritize the needs to build this capacity in Myanmar. The mission met with the then deputy 
minister and now minister of the Ministry of National Planning and Economic Development 
(MNPED), as well as senior MNPED officials and representatives from 15 other ministries. The 
meetings highlighted an urgent need for coordinated reforms to the national statistical system 
(NSS) and included government requests for support to develop capacity in many different parts 
of the statistical system. The areas where assistance was needed included training in statistics, 
a comprehensive review of the NSS, development of a national strategy for the development of 
statistics  (NSDS),  updating  an  outmoded  statistics  law,  establishment  of  a  high-level 
coordination mechanism for statistics, and the filling of data gaps in the short-, medium-, and 
long-term planning in various development sectors.  
 
2.  The technical assistance (TA) is intended to meet some of the initial priority needs of 
Myanmar’s NSS as part of what will necessarily be a long process to develop the country’s 
capacity to gather, organize, analyze, disseminate, and use statistics for its socioeconomic 
development. The project components were discussed with the Central Statistical Organization 
(CSO) and the Department of Planning of MNPED during a mission 24–25 January 2013 and 
through follow-up email correspondence. The government concurs with the impact, outcome, 
outputs, and key activities in the design and monitoring framework in Appendix 1.1 Under an 
initiative by the Statistics Division of the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for 
Asia and the Pacific, Myanmar’s development partners, including ADB and the World Bank, are 
coordinating  their  support  for  building  capacity  in  the  country’s  statistical  system.  The 
coordination  between  development  partners  is  aimed  at  demarcating  areas  of  assistance, 
complementing activities to optimize assistance, and avoiding duplication of efforts. 
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  As  Myanmar  makes  a  political  and  economic  transition,  credible  and  timely  official 
statistical information on social, economic, and environmental conditions will play a fundamental 
role in effective policy making, planning, and monitoring for economic growth, poverty reduction, 
and attainment of such development targets as the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). 
The current NSS is decentralized, with the MNPED’s CSO assigned a central role under the 
Central Statistical Authority Act of 1952. Most government ministries and departments have 
some statistical capacity to meet the data requirements in their sectors, but weak coordination 
between the CSO and ministries has led to severe systemic deficiencies. Adoption of the latest 
international statistical standards is lacking for the collection and compilation of statistics in 
many areas. Statistical efforts are duplicated unnecessarily. Data gaps exist due to too few 
surveys and censuses to periodically update key economic and social statistics. Data is lacking 
on the growing private sector, and existing statistics are underutilized. The quality and credibility 
of the available statistics are an issue, and technical and institutional capacity is weak. Myanmar 
needs  a  coherent  national  statistical  strategy  to  address  these  problems,  and  the  Central 
Statistical  Authority  Act,  which  does  not  provide  institutional  arrangements  for  effective 
coordination of statistical activities across the NSS, needs to be revised and brought up to date.  
 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 10 April 2013.

2  
4.  Statistics on Myanmar’s social and economic conditions and official data disseminated 
through the CSO website are limited, often old, and many are based on outdated statistical 
standards. Often the quality of data is suspect and official statistics are not perceived to be 
credible.2 Making quality statistics available is one of the four key objectives of Myanmar’s five-
year National Development Plan for 2012–2016, which accords high importance to balanced, 
inclusive  growth.  Improving  statistics  in  the  country  is  included  in  ADB’s  interim  country 
partnership strategy, 2012–2014 for Myanmar under the theme of good governance. An ADB 
study has also identified building statistical capacity as a key to a successful transition in 
Myanmar. 3  
 
5.  Myanmar also lags other Southeast Asian developing member countries in the statistical 
monitoring of international development objectives such as the MDGs. A 2009–2010 MDG 
report stated that Myanmar’s MDG reporting “differs from a standard MDG Report in that it relies 
exclusively on the Integrated Household Living Conditions Assessment II (IHLCA-II) survey data 
and only covers those MDGs which can be calculated on the basis of IHLCA-II data.”4 As a 
member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), Myanmar signed the 2001 
ASEAN Framework of Cooperation in Statistics, which committed members to support the 
regional planning and policy making of ASEAN bodies by providing comparable statistics in a 
timely manner. ASEAN’s aim to establish economic integration of the region by 2015 through 
the ASEAN Economic Community heightens the need for the compilation and sharing of reliable 
statistics by all of its members, including Myanmar.  
 
6.  Establishment of an effective NSS in Myanmar to deliver relevant, credible, and timely 
statistics is a prerequisite for successful developmental planning, as well as for efficient policy, 
program,  and  developmental  support  by  ADB  and  other  development  partners.  Reliable 
statistics will also be needed to measure development effectiveness in the country as transition 
progresses. The strategic and institutional capacity of the NSS of Myanmar and the statistical 
skills of staff need to be strengthened to enable Myanmar to adopt international standards in the 
collection, compilation, and timely dissemination of comparable official statistics. The TA will 
provide support to improve this statistical capacity, in line with the priorities of the National 
Development Plan, ADB’s interim country partnership strategy, and the regional cooperation 
needs of ASEAN. 
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The impact will be a national statistical system that can adequately respond to the data 
needs of development planning, policy making, and monitoring in Myanmar. The outcome will 
be strengthened institutional, strategic, and technical capacity in the NSS.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The TA will help the MNPED improve the strategic, institutional, and technical capacity 
of the NSS through five outputs, while collaborating with other development partners.  
                                                 
2 European  Union  External  Action  Service.  2007.  The  EC-Burma/Myanmar  Strategy  Paper  2007–2013. 
http://eeas.europa.eu/myanmar/csp/07_13_en.pdf

9.  Providing  inputs  to  a  national  strategy  for  the  development  of  statistics. The 
project will assess the institutional and legal framework of the NSS and Myanmar’s national 
accounts statistics. These assessments will serve as inputs for preparation of an NSDS by the 
government  in  collaboration  with  the  World  Bank  and  other  development  partners.  The 
comprehensive assessments will offer recommendations that can be integrated into the strategy 
and implemented over the medium and long terms. 
 
10.  Strengthening  strategic,  institutional,  legal  and  organizational  frameworks.  An 
updated statistics law will be drafted under the TA for wider consultation. The draft law will 
specify improved institutional, organizational, and coordination mechanisms for the constituents 
of the NSS and lay out their roles and responsibilities. Based on the TA-supported assessments 
and recommendations, the TA will also provide technical support to develop appropriate legal 
and institutional frameworks for the NSS to adopt and implement.  
 
11.  Training and skills development and building in-country training capacity. The TA 
will design and implement needed in-country and international statistics training programs, with 
proportionate participation by female staff. The project will also improve the CSO’s training 
capacity by identifying training needs and helping it establish a training unit, training of trainers, 
and training programs to meet recurring basic statistical training needs in the MNPED and line 
ministries. Computers and other training equipment will be provided on a limited basis to build 
training infrastructure. The TA will build statistical skills through short- and long-term training of 
statistics staff in basic statistics and such specialized areas of statistics as economic statistics 
(e.g., national accounts statistics and price statistics); the design and implementation of large-
scale surveys; and vital statistics and demography. Senior managers will be trained in statistics 
law  and  management  of  statistical  offices.  External  training  will  be  provided  mainly  by 
developing  partnerships  with  specialized  regional  training  centers,  such  as  the  Statistical 
Institute  for  Asia  and  the  Pacific  (SIAP)  in  Chiba,  Japan,  and  through  reputable  training 
institutions in developing countries with advanced statistical systems, such as India and the 
Philippines.5 This will promote capacity building through South–South cooperation.  
 
12.  Improving  key  economic  statistics.  Compilation  of  economic  statistics  will  be 
upgraded through improved methods, classifications, and source data availability. Particular 
emphasis will be put on upgrading the national accounts statistics (NAS) to the System of 
National Accounts (SNA) 2008 and improving price data.  This will follow a detailed assessment 
of the current status of these statistics, (particularly of NAS and price statistics), as well as of 
statistical  classifications  such  as  standard  industrial  classification  and  classification  of 
consumption expenditure.6 This review will identify methodological issues and the data and 
statistical infrastructure constraints to producing NAS through a production and expenditure 
approach that complies with the 2008 SNA. These activities will help the MNPED to document

sustainable socioeconomic development by promoting the understanding and advancement of official statistics 
through the training of professionals. The Government of Japan, as SIAP’s host government, extends cooperation 
to the institute through its Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications by providing the bulk of financial 
resources, administrative and infrastructure support. The government also sponsors all SIAP–JICA courses in the

countries, and estimate purchasing power parities of the world‘s economies.

4  
national  accounts  data  sources  and  compilation  methods  and  to  use  standard  statistical 
classifications. The TA will aim to strengthen the capacity of the staff in the MNPED and the 
agencies that provide input data for national accounts compilation and help them adopt the 
2008 SNA to the extent possible using the data available. It will develop and/or improve the 
methodology for price indexes for the wholesale and/or producers’ price index. The project will 
lay  particular  emphasis  on  learning-by-doing,  coaching,  and  mentoring  in  compiling  these 
statistics.  By  doing  so,  it  will  build  synergy  and  avoid  any  overlap  with  ongoing  training 
assistance in national accounts statistics being provided by the Japan International Cooperation 
Agency (JICA) and other development partners.7 
 
13.  Improving  data  dissemination  and  use  of  statistics.  The  TA  will  support  the 
improvement  of  statistics  publications  and  the  dissemination  of  official  statistics  with 
disaggregation  by  sex  and  other  factors.  It  will  help  the  CSO,  which  is  the  main  data 
disseminating agency, make data and metadata dissemination more timely through the print 
publication of reports, particularly the statistical yearbook, and through the CSO website and 
other  means  of  data  dissemination.  The  TA  will  help  develop  data  dissemination  policy 
guidelines and a data release calendar for key statistics, which will be important in making 
official statistics more accessible and up-to-date.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,450,000, of which $1,200,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis  by  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  (JFPR)  and  administered  by  ADB.  The 
government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office space, office 
supplies,  domestic  transportation,  and  other  in-kind  contributions.  The  cost  estimates  and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The TA will be implemented from June 2013 to August 2015. The MNPED will be the 
executing agency, and the CSO will be the implementing agency. A steering committee will be 
formed and will meet regularly to coordinate and monitor the TA activities. It will be chaired by 
the deputy minister of the MNPED who is in charge of the CSO, and include senior officials from 
the CSO, the Department of Planning, and other relevant agencies. ADB will coordinate with the 
line ministries and key development partners during implementation. An ADB TA focal point will 
provide administrative support for the conduct of all activities. ADB will participate in steering 
committee meetings as an observer. 
 
16.  ADB will oversee the implementation of the TA. The TA will require an estimated 35 
person-months of international consultant services and 17 person-months of national consultant 
services. The international services will comprise 8 person-months for statistical training and 
capacity building support; 5 person-months for institutional, organizational, and statistics law-
related reforms; 18 person-months to provide expertise on such topics as economic statistics, 
national accounts, price statistics, sample surveys, and data processing; and 4 person-months 
for in-country training on specialized statistical topics, as needed. The 17 person-months of 
national consultant services will be used to help implement the TA, support the international 
consultants,  and  assist  in  activities  related  to  the  statistics  law.  Training,  workshops,  and 
                                                 
7The work on national accounts statistics will also be coordinated with other interested development partners, such as 
the European Union and the International Monetary Fund, and with other work in related areas of economic 
statistics that are relevant to the compilation of national accounts statistics, such as government finance statistics, 
balance of payments, and price statistics.

5 
seminars  will  be  administered  by  the  consultants  from  the  TA  budget.  In  addition  to 
administering the TA and conducting monitoring and review missions, ADB staff will also act as 
resource persons in workshops and training. 
 
17.  The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. The consultants will be 
engaged as individuals rather than through a firm due to the variety of specialized services 
required. They will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance 
with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to 
time). The TA funds will be disbursed to and liquidated by the MNPED in accordance with the 
procedures and requirements of ADB’s advance payment facility. The procurement of any 
equipment will be made in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended 
from time to time). Proper turnover of equipment will also be ensured at the project’s completion 
date. 
 
18.  Good practices and lessons will be disseminated through workshops, seminars, and all 
of  the  websites  of  the  project  participants  and  agencies,  including  those  of  ADB  and  the 
government. ADB will coordinate with the Embassy of Japan and JICA counterparts regarding 
the  workshops,  seminars,  and  press  releases  associated  with  the  project  and  keep  them 
informed of project progress. Outcomes and lessons from the project will also be shared with 
the Embassy of Japan and JICA. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,200,000  to  the 
Government of Myanmar to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty 
Reduction for Capacity Development of the National Statistical System, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

10    Appendix 3   
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
   
A.  International Consultants 
 
1.  Institutional and statistics law expert (5 person-months). This expert will assist the 
director general of the Central Statistical Organization (CSO) in addressing the institutional and 
legal requirements of Myanmar’s national statistical system (NSS). The expert will preferably 
have  similar  experience  in  supporting  developing  countries  in  the  region  or  have  proven 
capabilities in handling responsibilities at very senior level in an NSS. The expert will:   
(i)  provide advice to the director general on organization and management of the 
statistical  activities  of  the  CSO,  review  the  CSO’s  organizational  structure, 
suggest organizational restructuring for improved organizational efficiency, and  
assist in the preparation of supporting documents that may be required; 
(ii)  undertake an in-depth review of the institutional set up of the NSS, including the 
technical and policy coordination mechanisms at the national and subnational 
levels, recommend appropriate institutional and legal setup for Myanmar’s NSS, 
based  on  best  practices  and  functioning  provisions  in  other  countries  with  
provisions for collecting sex-disaggregated data;  
(iii)  undertake an in-depth review of the current 1952 statistics law, suggest changes, 
and draft a reformed, up-to-date statistics law to meet the requirements of an 
NSS founded on United Nations Fundamental Principles of Official Statistics 
(UNFPOS), incorporating disaggregation by sex and other factors, as applicable; 
(iv)  organize advocacy sessions and conduct workshops for key stakeholders on 
management and organization related to the NSS, UNFPOS, the statistics law, 
and the National Strategy for the Development of Statistics (NSDS); 
(v)  consult key stakeholders extensively in the NSS, that is, both the producers and 
users of statistics;  
(vi)  work with the other development partners involved in the NSDS and prepare a 
report  on  institutional  issues,  with  recommendations  on  institutional, 
organizational, and legal reforms to be included in the NSDS;  
(vii)  participate  in  workshops,  seminars,  and  meetings  organized  by  other 
development partners engaged in the NSDS process and conduct presentations 
as a resource person; 
(viii)  provide technical support to the technical assistance (TA) project officer and 
prepare required documents, briefing materials, and presentations, as needed;  
(ix)  submit monthly progress reports and perform other tasks required by the project 
officer. 
 
2.  Lead economic statistics expert (6 person-months). This expert will provide overall 
guidance on the methodologies to be used for the compilation of national accounts statistics 
(NAS)  for  Myanmar  that  are  in  line  with  the  System  of  National  Accounts  (SNA)  2008. 
Possessing at least 20 years of practical experience in the compilation of national accounts 
statistics preferably in a national statistics office (NSO) in the developing countries in the region, 
he or she should have expertise in international statistical standards in the area of economic 
statistics and in implementing changes from 1968 SNA to 2008 SNA. The expert will:  
(i)  assess  Myanmar’s  current  procedures  for  compiling  annual  and  quarterly 
national accounts and price indexes or deflators for constant price estimates and 
identify  methodological  and  data  weaknesses,  gaps,  and  quality  issues  to 
improve the coverage and completeness of the national accounts estimates;  
(ii)  review  survey  questionnaires  and  other  data  collection  forms  and  suggest 
improvements to meet national accounts data needs, explore all possible data

Appendix 3  11 
sources for compiling NAS and relevant deflators, and suggest how the available 
data sources could be best used to improve the coverage; 
(iii)  prepare a medium-to-long-term work plan for implementing the 2008 SNA with 
time lines, identify input data needs from surveys, administrative data, and other 
sources, identify needed improvements in methodology that accord with the 2008 
SNA, and prepare a report to serve as an input for the NSDS; 
(iv)  develop  conceptual  frameworks,  methodologies,  and  techniques  essential  to 
2008 SNA compilation methods, including the design of survey forms for new 
data sources; 
(v)  supervise integration of supply-and-use tables in national accounts compilation; 
(vi)  work  with  staff  assigned  in  national  accounts  and  the  national  accounts 
consultant through mentoring and coaching to implement recommendations for 
upgrading current methods to 2008 SNA standards to the extent permitted by the 
available data; 
(vii)  draft  a  manual  of  sources  and  methods  for  NAS  compilation  with  national 
accounts staff; 
(viii)  suggest methods and approaches to improve state and/or regional domestic 
product estimates; 
(ix)  suggest mechanisms to be established for institutional and technical coordination 
across data suppliers and users to improve data availability, data reliability, the 
credibility of estimates, and to adopt sound methods of compiling data for NAS;  
(x)  identify the training needs of the national accounts staff in the Ministry of National 
Planning and Economic Development (MNPED) and other data source agencies, 
conduct training on SNA concepts, methodology, classifications, and standards, 
and provide mentoring through hands-on-training; 
(xi)  guide and supervise the work of the national accounts expert and coordinate with 
the price statistics and other experts in conducting training programs; 
(xii)  review  the  national  accounts  publications  and  suggest  areas  to  improve 
presentation of information disseminated through the CSO website and press 
releases;  
(xiii)  submit monthly progress reports to TA project officer and perform other related 
tasks. 
 
3.  National  accounts  expert  (6  person-months).  The  expert  will  work  under  the 
supervision and guidance of the lead economic statistics expert. Possessing at least 15 years of 
hands-on experience in the compilation of national accounts statistics preferably in an NSO in 
the developing countries in the region, he or she should have a strong theoretical background 
on the 2008 SNA and in the implementation of its recommendations. The expert will:  
(i)  help the lead economic statistics expert review the current practices of NAS 
compilation in Myanmar, identify methodological weaknesses, and review data 
sources and data gaps;  
(ii)  implement  recommendations  based  on  an  assessment  by  the  economic 
consultant  for  improvements  in  NAS  and  for  adopting  2008  SNA  with  data 
available from all sources; 
(iii)  conduct theoretical and practical training on the concepts and methods of 2008 
SNA, prepare training materials, and provide hands-on training during actual 
compilation of national accounts using 2008 SNA; 
(iv)  coordinate  with  other  development  partners  working  in  areas  of  economic 
statistics;  
(v)  submit monthly progress reports to the lead economic statistics  expert and TA 
project officer and perform other tasks required by the TA project officer.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
 
4.  Price statistics expert (2.5 person-months). The expert will review the existing price 
indexes and the methodologies used to compile them and recommend methodology based on 
available  data  systems  to  compile  new  indexes,  with  emphasis  on  the  wholesale  and/or 
producers’ price index. He or she should have a strong theoretical background in price statistics 
with practical experience on compiling them. The expert will:  
(i)  review and assess the current status of Myanmar’s price indexes to identify 
methodological and data coverage and weaknesses in data quality; 
(ii)  recommend improvements in price index compilation methods, coverage, and 
quality, including recommendations for the development of new indexes that are 
required and a methodology for computing wholesale and producers’ price index; 
(iii)  implement the approved recommendations to improve price index compilation in 
coordination with the lead economic statistics and national accounts experts; 
(iv)  provide training to staff on price index methodology, classifications, data quality, 
price  data  validation,  developing  a  wholesale  and/or  producers’  price  index, 
collection and compilation of data through data entry and computer programs; 
(v)  conduct hands-on training in price statistics with the lead consultant;  
(vi)  submit monthly progress reports to the lead consultant and the TA project officer 
and perform other tasks required by the TA project officer. 
 
5.  Sample survey activity expert (2 person-months). The expert will be engaged to meet 
the survey needs for filling data gaps in selected areas of national accounts statistics. She or he 
should have a strong theoretical background in survey design with practical experience in the 
design, execution, and estimation procedures of economic surveys. The expert will:  
(i)  design  the  sample  survey,  data  collection  questionnaire,  and  estimation 
procedures for the surveys in the selected areas and develop manuals detailing 
concepts, questionnaires used, and instructions for collecting data; 
(ii)  provide extensive training to CSO staff in survey design and estimation methods, 
with practical examples and instruction during conduct of field operations; 
(iii)  conduct training for enumerators, supervisors, and data processors with the lead 
economic statistics, the national accounts, and the price statistics experts; 
(iv)  submit monthly progress reports to the lead consultant and/or the TA project 
officer and perform other tasks required by the TA project officer. 
 
6.  Data  processing  expert  (1.5  person-months).  The  expert  will  develop  the  data 
processing program for the survey activity in coordination with the consultant working on the 
development of a sample survey activity. She or he will conduct training in data processing for 
staff directly involved in the activity. He or she should have a strong background in information 
technology and in developing data processing programs for surveys, be familiar with survey 
data processing software, and possess practical experience in survey data processing. The 
expert will:  
(i)  develop data processing programs for the survey results, including manuals on 
the different modules, and build the capacity of CSO staff assigned; 
(ii)  test  the  accuracy,  correctness,  functionalities,  and  acceptability  of  the  data 
processing program in coordination with the sample survey consultant;  
(iii)  revise the program based on results of this testing, conduct a retest, and finalize 
the program; 
(iv)  conduct training on the different modules of the program;  
(v)  provide guidance to staff designated to do the actual data processing;  
(vi)  submit monthly progress reports to the lead consultant and/or the TA project 
officer and perform other tasks required by the TA project officer.

Appendix 3  13 
 
7.  Statistics training and capacity building expert (8 person-months). The expert will 
identify the training needs of NSS staff, recommend a training strategy for official statisticians, 
and help the CSO establish an in-house training unit. She or he will develop appropriate regular 
training programs in the CSO to be implemented by the CSO with other national statistical 
agencies, institutions, and universities. The expert will implement a series of training sessions to 
build the CSO’s training unit’s capacity. Specifically, the expert will:   
(i)  assess the strength and capacity of statistics staff at different levels in the CSO 
and ministries based on their educational qualifications and technical statistical 
skills using a sex disaggregation approach and identify the training and skills 
needed in the short, medium, and long terms;  
(ii)  suggest training programs for upgrading the statistical skills and educational 
qualifications of the statisticians in the CSO and other government agencies to 
equip them to collect, compile, analyze, and disseminate high-quality data in a 
professional manner; 
(iii)  suggest a mix of in-house, in-country, and international training programs,  and 
identify  in-country  and  international  institutions  of  specialized  agencies  and 
NSOs in neighboring countries that could provide this training,  
(iv)  review the existing internal training facilities in the CSO, and help the CSO 
establish a functional training unit to meet certain basic and intermediate training 
needs of MNPED and other ministries and departments; 
(v)  suggest what infrastructure and equipment the CSO training unit needs for these 
training programs and undertake procurement of selected items; 
(vi)  develop  an  appropriate  curriculum  for  the  training  program  and  prepare  the 
training  and  lecture  materials  including  case  studies,  hands-on  exercises, 
projects, and discussion; 
(vii)  identify trainers in the CSO and other departments and/or ministries and conduct 
a series of training-for-trainers courses; 
(viii)   conduct or assist in implementing training programs to be undertaken by the 
CSO’s training unit, prepare a report for each training course, include evaluation 
by participants, and improve the course contents based on feedback; 
(ix)  coordinate  and  organize  training  programs  and  the  selection  of  trainees  for 
training  programs  under  the  TA  in  collaboration  with  the  project  steering 
committee and other project consultants and ensure proportionate representation 
of women staff in all training programs; 
(x)  undertake a review of the major statistical publications of the CSO and build staff 
capacity  to  improve  presentation  of  tables  and  graphics  in  regular  printed 
statistical  publications  and  data  releases  and  to  include  brief  analyses  with 
simple statistical commentaries that highlight interesting stories from the data; 
(xi)  assess  the  data  dissemination  and  release  practices  of  the  CSO  and  other 
constituents of the NSS through the CSO website and help the CSO disseminate 
as much useful data as possible in user-friendly, downloadable formats;  
(xii)  establish  guidelines  for  data  releases  with  sex  and  other  important 
disaggregation, as well as time lines for the release of key statistics and related 
metadata; 
(xiii)  participate in the workshops, seminars, and meetings organized by ADB and 
other development partners and make presentations as a resource person; 
(xiv)  work closely with other international consultants engaged under the TA to help 
the project officer coordinate training under the project; 
(xv)  submit monthly progress reports to TA project officer and perform other tasks 
they require;

14  Appendix 3 
 
 
 
8.  Statistics training experts (4 person-months). Depending upon capacity building needs 
prioritized, the training experts will be engaged to conduct short-term training programs. The 
experts will have a strong background in the required areas of statistical training and should 
have practical experience putting theory into practice. The experts will:  
(i)  coordinate with the statistics training and capacity building expert to design and 
conduct training programs, and prepare comprehensive training materials for use 
as references by trainers and trainees in the future; 
(ii)  identify additional online resources for trainees to learn from; 
(iii)  emphasize the practical aspects of the training and its direct relevance to the 
compilation of statistics; 
(iv)  solicit  feedback  and  suggestions  from  the  trainees  and  improve  the  training 
programs based on this information; 
(v)  submit  interim  and  final  training  reports,  including  evaluation  reports,  to  the 
statistics training and capacity building expert, the CSO, and to the TA project 
officer and perform other tasks required by the TA project officer. 
 
B.  National Consultants  
 
9.  National consultant for the project (15 person-months). The consultant will work with 
the  director  general  of  the  CSO  and  assist  the  international  consultants  in  technical  and 
administrative matters. She or he will:  
(i)  assist the director general and international consultants in handling the technical 
assistance and administrative matters of the project and in the procurement of 
equipment, as needed; 
(ii)  help  other  project  consultants  and/or  the  TA  project  officer  carry  out  their 
activities smoothly by networking with relevant ministries and departments; 
(iii)  provide  guidance  to  staff  working  in  the  NSS  and/or  TA  project  officer  and 
conduct training programs; 
(iv)  submit monthly progress reports to the TA project officer and perform other tasks 
required by the TA project officer. 
 
10.   National consultant for statistics law (2 person-months). The national consultant with 
extensive legal knowledge of Myanmar’s legal and administrative system will: 
(i)  provide support to the institutional and statistics law expert in drafting the new 
statistics law and related documents in line with the legal system; 
(ii)  perform other tasks required by the lead consultant and the TA project officer.
